title: How were comas treated before the age of medical technology? Did people just die? - Quora

response.answer_text: Detail from The Extraction of the Stone of Madness, a painting by Hieronymus Bosch depicting trepanation (c.1488–1516). public domain How were comas treated before the age of medical technology? Did people just die? Trepanning is an ancient practice. Sometimes it was successful and sometimes it wasn’t. Some families would react with horror at the idea of their loved one being “cut on” and others would be willing to go against prevalent religious beliefs. Many cultures believed putting an amulet, scarab, or religious item on, under or near the patient would help. Prayers were offered to the relevant deity and if part of the belief system, they offered sacrifices to their gods.  The perimeter of the hole in this trepanated Neolithic skull is rounded off by ingrowth of new bony tissue, indicating that the patient survived the operation. By Rama Drilling or cutting a hole in someone’s head was tried in the Americas, Europe, and Asia. As noted, if the hole was rounded, healing had begun. Many physicians knew to check eyes for pupil irregularities and, of course, the checking of urine was a standard procedure combined with prayer. Bloodletting was common and did much more harm than good. Hippocrates was the first to note that malaria-induced convulsions in insane patients was able to cure them. In the Middle Ages, some physicians observed the same phenomenon after a severe bout of fever; such as after cholera epidemics in insane asylums. These early medical practitioners knew something was wrong with the brain, but knowing and being able to do something about it are not the same. Life support was non-existent, so YES, most people died. To stand by a bed and know that nothing can be done, that one’s prayers are ineffective, and that the loved one was going to die must have been agonizing.  The History of Shock Therapy in Psychiatry
